1.name: Jaylen Summers
1.about: Summers ends the season as the projected No. 1 pick, fueled by generational athleticism and relentless rim pressure. His explosive first step and two-way impact make him the most dynamic guard prospect in years, projecting as a cornerstone capable of elevating an NBA franchise.

2.name: Trey James
2.about: James closes the season projected second overall, remaining in the two-man race for No. 1. His electric play, dynamic creation, and deep shooting range make him a franchise-changing guard. In transition, he scored 1.12 points per possession, ranking in the 92nd percentile nationally.

3.name: Nicola Mancini
3.about: Mancini projects as a cornerstone guard prospect, blending defensive toughness with advanced shot creation. Synergy ranks him in the 92nd percentile guarding pick-and-roll handlers, holding opponents to 0.68 PPP in isolation and forcing turnovers on 21% of possessions, highlighting All-Star upside potential.
3.pro_comp: Derrick White with more scoring punch

4.name: Adam Riley
4.about: Firmly projected as a top-five pick, Riley grades in the 95th percentile nationally in rim protection while flashing touch as a roll man, scoring at 1.12 points per possession. His defense makes him a safe anchor, with offensive upside still untapped.

5.name: Saúl Segura
5.about: After a season at F.C. Barcelona, Segura enters the draft as a potential franchise cornerstone. Size, mid-range scoring, and defensive versatility keep him in the top tier, though lingering questions about strength, efficiency, and playmaking prevent him from securing the top spot.

6.name: Taji Anikulapo-Kuti
6.about: With a 6’6” frame and 7’3” wingspan, Anikulapo-Kuti has solidified himself as a top-10 pick. Holding opponents to 0.58 PPP as the primary defender, he showcases elite disruption. Budding offensive flashes boost his upside despite perimeter shooting concerns.

7.name: Sincere Johnston
7.about: Johnston heads to the draft as a top-10 lock after a breakout sophomore campaign, averaging over 20 PPG and establishing himself as one of the nation’s most dynamic scorers. Defense and efficiency remain concerns, but his iso scoring makes him a premier offensive talent.

8.name: Joshua Boston
8.about: Boston’s stock has steadied as a top-ten pick, with teams valuing elite athleticism, size, and scoring upside. He projects as a quality starter and fringe All-Star, capable of swinging games with explosiveness, even if decision-making and efficiency never fully stabilize.

9.name: Ismaël Aït Salah
9.about: Aït Salah projects as a top-ten pick, boasting one of the highest ceilings in the class. Averaging 4.5 APG in limited minutes, he showcases rare passing vision. Defense and versatility anchor his appeal, though his shooting is still developing at this stage.

10.name: Riley Jamison
10.about: Jamison is now viewed as a top-10 pick after a stellar freshman season at Arizona, averaging 18.9 PPG and 5.4 APG with strong efficiency. Scouts overlook size concerns thanks to his elite shot-making, playmaking, and offensive consistency.

11.name: Isaiah Bailey
11.about: Bailey’s stock sits around top-ten pick status, with teams valuing his sturdy frame and polished scoring package. Iso creation and deep shooting give him instant NBA offense, while long-term ceiling depends on rounding out defense and playmaking.

12.name: Terrence James
12.about: James has cemented his spot in the lottery as one of the draft’s most dependable 3&D wings. Ranked in the 78th percentile on catch-and-shoot threes and 74th percentile defending spot-ups, his clearly defined role improves his draft appeal despite limited creation.

13.name: Bernard Johnson
13.about: Johnson’s stock rose steadily at St. John’s after transferring from Georgia, cementing himself as a reliable inside-out forward. Teams value his ability to stretch the floor and score with his back to the basket. Sitting 13th on the board, he’s firmly in lottery territory.

14.name: Chancellor Harris
14.about: Harris has risen to lottery consideration. Shooting consistency and versatility allow teams to value him highly. Athleticism and size enable rim attacks and creation, while decision-making and defense continue refining for high-level competition, establishing him as a high-upside prospect.

15.name: Jaylen Simmons
15.about: Simmons closes the freshman season in the middle of first-round conversation. Steadiness on offense, left-handed scoring, and improved defensive instincts make him a high-upside guard with potential to translate effectively at the next level.

16.name: Darius Hall
16.about: Hall has risen into the middle of the first round, with scouts intrigued by immense potential. Rim protection and athletic finishing remain strengths, though shooting and decision-making need refinement before he maximizes upside at the professional level.

17.name: Mark Bolton
17.about: Bolton projects as a mid-to-early lottery pick thanks to consistency and strong play at Duke. Scouts see him as a reliable interior presence able to provide early rotation minutes and stabilize frontcourt lineups while contributing on both ends.

18.name: Terrance Edwards
18.about: Edwards has settled into the back end of the first round. His 7’0” wingspan and scoring versatility allow contributions across multiple positions. Rugged play and experience help him handle bigger opponents, though finishing through contact remains an area to refine.

19.name: Kason Smith
19.about: Once a 5-star recruit, Smith justified the hype at Alabama. Alongside teammate Sincere Johnston, they form a dynamic scoring duo. Smith’s steady playmaking, high-IQ reads, and improving scoring confidence push him into first-round conversations as a future floor general.

20.name: Jack Rice
20.about: Once viewed as a lottery talent, Rice steadied as a projected pick around 20, valued for shooting and maturity. High-floor spot-up efficiency (1.09 PPP, 78th percentile per Synergy) projects cleanly into an NBA rotation role, making him a reliable specialist wing.

21.name: Aviel Elbaz
21.about: Elbaz closes the cycle in first-round conversation, shining as Hapoel Tel Aviv’s crafty engine. His pick-and-roll playmaking and poise set him apart. Not explosive athletically, his mature game projects effectively to the NBA, making him a strong, polished guard prospect.

22.name: Dave Mosley
22.about: Mosley closes the cycle as one of the draft’s better bigs. Physicality, post scoring, and rebounding stand out. Offensive range is limited, but toughness and interior presence make him a compelling frontcourt option for teams seeking a reliable big with upside.

23.name: Semaj Jenkins
23.about: Jenkins closes his UCLA career proving he can hang with bigger wings despite being undersized. Nearly 7’0” wingspan allows him to contest shots, grab boards, and disrupt passing lanes. Energy and versatility translate to the next level, projecting him as a rotational forward.

24.name: Xavion Booker
24.about: Viewed as a mid-20s selection, Booker offers intriguing upside with natural scoring instincts and left-handed creativity. Defenses exposed inefficiency at USC, but pedigree, confidence, and shot-making flashes keep him in the conversation as a developmental guard with long-term upside.

25.name: Jadyn Mora
25.about: Mora closes his Villanova career into first-round conversation. Deep shooting, isolation skills, and offensive poise make him a reliable scoring option. Undersized, but intelligence and craftiness project him as a steady, NBA-ready guard capable of spacing and creating offense.

26.name: Kavon Williams
26.about: Williams settled into the end of the first-round range after a strong Pittsburgh season. Athleticism, scoring instincts, and rim attacks make him intriguing, though consistency and perimeter shooting need refinement for long-term NBA impact.

27.name: Cam Lee
27.about: Now projected at the back end of the first, scouts overlook size concerns and view him as a valuable bench contributor who can ignite an offense with energy and scoring bursts, though he lacks a defined two-way game at the next level.

28.name: Dustin Anderson
28.about: Anderson finishes as a solid first-round prospect with intriguing upside. Known for leaping ability and mid-range scoring, he excites in transition but struggles from deep (28%) and defensively. He’s the second of two projected Sooner first-round picks.

29.name: Iago Barcellos
29.about: Barcellos closes his international season as a versatile frontcourt prospect, sitting 29th on the final big board. A 7’2” wingspan allows rim protection, rebounding, and floor spacing. Strength and post polish remain areas to improve for NBA readiness.

30.name: Mathys Moreau
30.about: Moreau ends the season as a projected second-rounder, sliding after scouts soured on defense and rebounding. His size and floor-spacing ability at the five spot make him a specialist capable of carving out an NBA role despite limitations.

31.name: Mahlik Joseph
31.about: Joseph finished his junior year at Notre Dame as a steady two-way guard thriving off the bounce. Not flashy, but toughness and downhill ability keep him in the second-round mix as a depth guard with rotational upside at the next level.

32.name: Niklas Helm
32.about: Helm’s decision to remain overseas slowed his draft rise, but the German big offers size, mobility, and rim protection. Offensive polish limits upside, yet he’s viewed as a stash candidate worth monitoring for development into a potential rotational NBA big.

33.name: Andrew Bolden Jr.
33.about: Bolden settles as a mid-to-late first-rounder, valued for versatile defense and toughness. Teams see him as a plug-and-play role player capable of impacting games defensively while continuing to develop offensive polish for long-term rotational value.

34.name: Kristiāns Lapiņš
34.about: The Latvian big closes as a fringe second-rounder. Ability to erase shots and hit mid-range looks is intriguing, but conditioning, motor, and translation to the NBA push him into late flyer territory with upside if developed.

35.name: Jabari Henry
35.about: Henry’s athleticism and rim pressure pop on film, but at 6’6” he’s undersized for the NBA frontcourt. Without reliable shooting or defensive versatility, he projects as a tough sell beyond training camp opportunities, despite evident competitive tools.

36.name: Justinas Jakčinskas
36.about: Settling into the second round, Jakčinskas profiles as a long-term developmental big. Defense and mobility give him a path to carve out a role despite offensive limitations, projecting as a rotational contributor once polished for professional play.

37.name: Nicholas Falk
37.about: Falk’s senior season at Creighton cemented him as one of the best shooters in the class. Deep range and quick release carve a clear NBA role. Age and limited tools cap ceiling, but shooting guarantees second-round attention as a specialist.

38.name: Luke Causey
38.about: Causey closed his senior season at Michigan as one of the nation’s most skilled stretch-fives. At 7’0” with a reliable jumper, he offers immediate floor-spacing value. Limited mobility caps upside, but shooting ensures early second-round interest.

39.name: Cody Meadows
39.about: Meadows’ freshman year at Baylor showed flashes of two-way potential. Inconsistency and thin frame raise NBA readiness questions, but young size and wing upside keep him on long-term boards as a developmental prospect.

40.name: Mark Smiley
40.about: Smiley projects as a second-round selection after a steady Iowa junior year, averaging 16.2 PPG and 40% from three. Reliable shooting and iso scoring establish a clear offensive niche, though athletic and defensive limits cap overall ceiling.

41.name: Miles Gibson
41.about: Gibson projects as an early second-round prospect built on strength and toughness. Excels bullying opponents and cleaning the glass, but lack of stretch skills limits versatility and long-term upside despite physical tools for interior impact.

42.name: Davonte Huntley
42.about: Huntley’s junior year at Michigan State highlighted mid-post scoring and interior toughness. Lack of perimeter skills and defensive versatility limit NBA outlook, profiling as a physical forward suited for overseas or G League development.

43.name: Alex Humphrey
43.about: Humphrey wrapped up his Florida career as a dependable floor spacer. At 6’7”, shooting and maturity stand out, but limited creation and average defense place him firmly in the late second-round mix as a specialist role player.

44.name: Alex Mahon
44.about: Mahon emerged at Washington as a crafty shot-maker with deep three-point range. Ability to generate looks off the dribble is valuable, but inconsistent efficiency and streaky defense suggest a bench role projection at the next level.

45.name: Samy Delaunay
45.about: The French wing flashed explosive athleticism and finishing, thriving in transition. Shooting and feel are raw, but youth and tools keep him on radars as a long-term stash or late flyer with developmental upside.

46.name: Kevin Tyson
46.about: Tyson’s sophomore year at Missouri showed elite burst and rim pressure at 6’7”. Limited shooting and strength make him a project, but slashing ability could translate if physical development progresses.

47.name: Jake Smith
47.about: Smith produced rebounding and interior scoring at Nebraska. Limited mobility and age cap NBA upside, projecting him as a tough big man suitable for overseas or G League minutes.

48.name: Tristian Roach
48.about: Roach closes the cycle in the back end of the second round. Rugged, physical play and 7’0” wingspan allow him to dominate paint matchups and finish blow-by drives. Perimeter shooting and consistency remain concerns.

49.name: Aaron Carrillo
49.about: Carrillo impressed as a freshman with power dunks and energy plays. Raw offensively and prone to mistakes, but physicality and athletic upside make him intriguing long-term for development or bench roles.

50.name: Matthias Hamilton
50.about: Hamilton’s senior season confirmed his role as a 3PT floor spacer. Despite size and shooting, lack of shot creation and defensive impact projects him as a fringe rotational sniper at the next level.

51.name: Jonathan Ford
51.about: Ford closes his freshman season as a high-upside second-round prospect. Young, athletic, and able to attack the rim, he can contribute off the bench. Decision-making and perimeter shooting will determine how high he can climb long-term.

52.name: Danny Schneider
52.about: A 24-year-old senior, Schneider brings experience and craft as a finisher. Limited athletic upside caps ceiling, but size and touch give him a chance to compete for a camp spot as a versatile depth big.

53.name: Brayan Hunt
53.about: Hunt carved out his Gonzaga role as a reliable spot-up shooter. At 22, profile is limited beyond floor spacing, but quick release and confidence from deep make him a late target for shooting-needy teams.

54.name: Eric Welch
54.about: A lefty sharpshooter with deep range, Welch impressed with mechanics and size for a guard. Lacks athleticism and defensive chops, which may restrict NBA chances, but projects as a shooting specialist for bench or rotational roles.

55.name: Julian McGhee
55.about: McGhee brings strength and explosiveness as a rim attacker. Still raw offensively and undersized at the 4, thrives in energy minutes but projects as a bench piece unless skill level grows.

56.name: Bruno Correa
56.about: The young Spaniard is a physical wing who bullies smaller defenders inside. Shooting limitations and average quickness raise questions, but at 19 he offers stash appeal if offensive polish improves.

57.name: Abdoulaye Saint-Laurent
57.about: At nearly 7’3” wingspan, Saint-Laurent has defensive tools as a rim protector and some stretch flashes. Offensive polish lags and he is foul-prone, but upside as a modern defensive big is evident with proper development.

58.name: Makai Bridges
58.about: A steady two-way guard, Bridges thrives in the mid-range with defense-first instincts. Lack of NBA athleticism caps ceiling as a role player, but toughness and IQ make him a candidate for pro careers overseas.

59.name: Rickey Britt
59.about: Kansas product with quickness and playmaking flashes. Small frame limits defense, but shooting growth offers pathway to backup PG minutes. Strength will be key to sticking at the next level.

60.name: Joey Anderson
60.about: Anderson is a sturdy post scorer with flashes of stretch ability. Mobility and defensive versatility hinder profile, but frame and touch could keep him in pro rotations outside the NBA.
